journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics

title-group.article-title: Covariate Adjustment Strategy Increases Power in the Randomized Controlled Trial With Discrete-Time Survival Endpoints

bio.title: Authors
bio.p: MARYAM SAFARKHANI is a PhD candidate at the department of Methodology and Statistics, Utrecht University, Box 80140, 3508 TC Utrecht, The Netherlands, e-mail: m.safarkhani@uu.nl. Her research interests focus on power and survival analyses, optimal design, as well as multilevel and latent variable analyses.

MIRJAM MOERBEEK, PhD, is an associate professor at the department of Methodology and Statistics, Utrecht University, POBox 80140, 3508 TC Utrecht, The Netherlands, e-mail: m.moerbeek@uu.nl, tel: +31-(0) 302531450. Her research interests include optimal design, structural equation modeling and multilevel modeling, power, and survival analyses.

abstract.p: In a randomized controlled trial, a decision needs to be made about the total number of subjects for adequate statistical power. One way to increase the power of a trial is by including a predictive covariate in the model. In this article, the effects of various covariate adjustment strategies on increasing the power is studied for discrete-time survival endpoints; the circumstances are examined under which the covariate adjustment results in a sufficient increase in power. Using a predictive covariate may increase the costs for each subject, so it is useful to quantify when using a covariate is a cost-efficient strategy. The results reveal that using a covariate is highly recommended if the costs for measuring the covariate are relatively small and the correlation with the outcome sufficiently high.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The randomized controlled trial (RCT) is considered the most rigorous method for determining treatment effectiveness. Subjects in RCTs are randomly allocated to receive one of several treatments; the main aim is to compare one or more new treatments to a control. Various outcome variables can be considered for RCTs, such as continuous, binary, categorical (ordinal or nominal), counts, and survival endpoints. RCTs with survival endpoints that specify whether and, if so, when a specific event occurs, are encountered in social and behavioral as well as biomedical sciences. For example, Masyn (2003) evaluates whether behavioral couples therapy would effectively decrease the risk of drinking and the domestic violence of alcohol-dependent males. All the subjects are randomized to one of three treatment groups and followed for 1 year. In each 2-month period, domestic violence is recorded if it occurs.

The timing of events is continuous if the target event occurs at any point in time. In this situation, time is measured using precise units as widely used in biomedical sciences, where the main event is often death. To deal with this type of survival data, continuous-time survival analyses can be performed; the most popular model is the Cox proportional hazard model (Cox, 1972).

In social and behavioral sciences, however, the observed time might not be measured precisely and has to be recorded in discrete intervals for the following reasons: (1) Some events occur at a precise point in time but are only recorded at the end of each interval, as is common in prospective studies. Mental health professionals, for instance, might want to evaluate the effect of an inpatient alcohol treatment program on the risk of a drinking relapse among newly released patients. To examine the patients’ drinking status, it might be too expensive to contact them frequently. So investigators might consider discrete intervals for collecting the data, for example, years, months, or weeks. (2) Some events can only occur at discrete points in time. High school students for example can only graduate a few times a year, that is, at the end of each semester. (3) Data collection requirements may force researchers to consider intervals for recording time, especially in retrospective studies where subjects may not remember the exact time the event occurred. For example, it is difficult for adolescents to recall their exact age when they had their first suicidal thought.

To analyse this kind of data, discrete-time survival analysis is applied and the most common model is the discrete-time hazard model, as is well described by Singer and Willett (1993, 2003). This model is a generalized linear model (GLM) and uses a combination of several logistic regression models, one for each time period. The model is of special interest because it can be easily used with standard software packages such as SPSS, SAS, R, and Mplus.

In recent decades, there has been growing interest in an experimental study with adequate statistical power, that is, to detect treatment effects with sufficient probability. As we know, the power depends on the sample size. If the sample size is extremely small, the effect of the treatment may not be detected at all, but including numerous subjects in a study might be a waste of time and money. The increasing interest in achieving a desired power has heightened the need for computational tools for calculating the required number of subjects before conducting trials. The power and sample size calculations have been extensively studied in continuous-time survival analyses. Many articles and books have been published in this field, for example, Chow, Shao, and Wang (2008), Julious (2010), Collett (2003), Machin, Cheung, and Parmar (2006), and Hosmer, Lemeshow, and May (2008). And many software packages perform these calculations, such as nQuery Advisor 7.0 (Elashoff, 2005) and PASS (Hintze, 2008). The relation between the power and the sample size has recently been investigated in studies with discrete-time endpoints. Jóźwiak and Moerbeek (2012) derive the required number of subjects for sufficient power in an RCT with two equally sized treatment groups. This study has also been investigated for Cluster Randomized Trials by adding a random effect at the cluster level to the discrete-time hazard model, which is then called a generalized linear mixed model (Moerbeek, in press).

Increasing the sample size not only increases the statistical power but also the costs of the study. Many researchers have recently opted to seek alternative methods for increasing the power without increasing the sample size. One way is by including a covariate and applying a multivariate analysis instead of a univariate one (Allison, 1995). Recent studies have focused on this method of analyzing variance models (Allison, Allison, Faith, Paultre, & Pi-Sunyer, 1997), continuous-time survival analysis (Hernandez, Eijkemans, & Steyerberg, 2006), and on trials with dichotomous outcomes (see, for instance, Hernandez, Steyerberg, & Habbema, 2004; Turner et al., 2012).

Not much has been done to evaluate the efficacy of including a predictive covariate in increasing the power of discrete-time survival analysis. This article assesses the extent to which the use of a predictive covariate can increase the power of an RCT with discrete-time survival endpoints. We focus on three covariate adjustment strategies: adjustment any time, adjustment only if the covariate has a significant effect on the outcome, and adjustment only if the covariate is imbalanced across treatment conditions. We also consider a survival function with a decreasing, constant and increasing hazard of event occurrence across time. Hernandez et al. (2006) investigate the effect of covariate adjustment strategies in RCTs with continuous-time survival endpoints, but only take a decreasing hazard function into account.

A principal reason to measure the additional covariate on each subject is to avoid rising trial costs. One might wonder whether it is useful to measure a covariate and reduce the sample size needed to achieve a desired power. Allison (1995) derives a simple closed form expression, making it possible to determine when measuring a covariate is useful for achieving a powerful trial. So the second aim of this article is to properly address the problem of trials with discrete-time survival endpoints.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. Section 2 is a brief introduction to the discrete-time hazard model. Section 3 describes the design factors and their corresponding levels in our simulation study, introduces the adjustment strategies, and shows which criteria are used to evaluate the strategies and compare their performances. Section 4 presents the results. Section 5 addresses the practical issue of the financial costs of covariate usage. We also illustrate the application of the adjustment strategies using two examples taken from social and behavioral research in Section 6. Conclusions and a discussion are given in Section 7.

It can be concluded that the risk of event occurrence in period

To assess the effect of predictors on the population discrete-time hazard function and compare the risk of event occurrence between various treatments, the population discrete-time hazard model is applied. It is a generalized linear model (GLM) and models the risk of event occurrence for subject i in period
j
as a function of the predictors. For five time periods and a logit link it is written as:

Here
D
i j
is a time indicator for the subject i and assumes the value 1 in period j and 0 in all the other periods. The variable Z indicates the treatment condition and is 0 for subjects in the control group and 1 for those in the experimental group. The variable C is a binary covariate assumed to denote gender in this article and subsequently scored as 0 for males and 1 for females. Both of the variables are time-invariant, which means the subjects cannot change their treatment condition or covariate value in the course of the study. The right-hand side of the formula is composed of two terms. In the first pair of brackets, the αs are multiplied by their corresponding time indicators and act as multiple intercepts, one for each period. Each intercept parameter α j represents the value of the logit hazard (log odds of event occurrence) in period j for the baseline group, which is a subset of the population where all the predictors are equal to zero. In the second pair of brackets, the βs are multiplied by their respective predictors and assess the effect of one unit increase in the value of the associated predictors on the logit of the probability of event occurrence in every period. The αs can represent the baseline logit hazard function and the βs the size of the vertical shift in this function corresponding to one unit difference in the predictors. The size of the gap is assumed to be identical across the periods. In other words, the model assumes that the effect of the predictors is constant over time, that is, the proportional odds assumption.

To fit discrete-time hazard models, data should be constructed in the form of a person-period data set. In this type of data, each subject has a separate record for each period provided he or she is still at risk of event occurrence in that period. Subject i, who experiences the event or drops out from the study for other reasons in period j, only has
J i
records in the data. Each record describes the subject’s values on
D 1
, ⋯
D 5
,
Z
,
C
, and the event indicator. This variable specifies whether the event occurs in the specific period and assumes the value 1 if the subject experiences the event.

The model parameters can be estimated based on full Maximum Likelihood (ML) techniques using the regular logistic regression machinery available in most general purpose statistical software packages. The Maximum Likelihood Estimates of parameters is obtained by maximizing the following ML equation:

sec.title: 2.1. Weibull Survival Function
sec.p:
We assume that the underlying time variable T is continuous. Different continuous functions can be used to describe its probability density function such as Exponential, Weibull, Lognormal, Gamma, or Gumbel. The Weibull distribution function is a common and flexible model for this purpose and we use it to model the survival for the baseline group. Without a loss of generality, time can be scaled between 0 and 1 with 0 as the beginning of the trial (
t 0
) and 1 the end of the trial (
t 5
). Then the Weibull density function with shape parameter
τ
and scale parameter λ is as follows:
f ( t ) =
λ
τ
t
τ − 1
exp ( −
λ
t τ
)
; t > 0.

The cumulative density function is given by
F ( t ) = 1 −

τ
. According to this definition, the Weibull survival function for the baseline group is expressed as
S ( t ) =
e
− λ
t τ
and the corresponding baseline hazard function is determined by
h ( t ) = λ τ

as the overall proportion of subjects in the baseline group who experience the event at some point in time during the study (Galbraith & Marschner, 2002). Then for any given value of ω, different patterns for the baseline survival and hazard function are defined, as are shown in Figure 1 for
ω
= 0.8
and three different values of τ. In this figure, the survival functions can be found in the upper half and the corresponding baseline hazard probabilities in the lower half. If
τ
=
1 3
, the hazard probability is the highest at the beginning of the trial and decreases over time, which corresponds to trials where many subjects only experience the event after the study has been going on for a short time. We also observe that the survival function for this pattern drops rapidly during the periods with the highest risk of event occurrence and then declines slowly. For τ = 1, the hazard probability is constant across time, which implies that the corresponding survival function is almost linear over time periods, and for τ = 3, the hazard probability is the lowest at the beginning and increases over time and indicates trials with the highest risk concentrated toward the end. This pattern can be illustrated by the smaller reduction in the associated survival function at the beginning of the trial and the steeper reduction toward the end of the trial. For each survival pattern, five time periods are used. Using the survival probabilities
S j
at the end of period j, we are able to calculate the baseline discrete-time hazard probabilities at discrete interval j by considering the relation between
h (
t j
)
and
S (

)
as given in Equation 1.

sec.title: 3. Materials and Methods
sec.p: This research focuses on RCTs with two groups, an experimental group, which is given a treatment, and a control group. The treatment is randomly assigned with equal probability to half the subjects. The impact of one binary covariate on increasing the power to detect the treatment effect is examined. Here, the covariate is gender; of course, any binary covariate can be used. Random allocation may result in a correlation between gender and treatment condition. In subsection 3.1, we first identify design factors and their corresponding levels, which are used in our simulation study. Then model and adjustment strategies are introduced and finally the criteria used for the evaluation of the strategies are given.

Three logit hazard functions for the baseline group are defined with three survival patterns using different values for the Weibull shape parameter (τ), see Figure 1. For this figure, the overall surviving proportion at the end of the study for the baseline group is assumed to be 0.2 (
ω
= 0.8
). Attrition is assumed to be constant across time and four levels for attrition rate are defined:
r = 0 ,
0.05 ,
0.10 ,
and

.

There are 864 possible combinations of all the design factor levels called simulation conditions. Using the program R, 10,000 data sets are generated in each simulation condition if there is a treatment effect (OR(β1) > 1) and 100,000 data sets if there is not (OR(β1) = 1). For a few simulation combinations, more data sets are simulated, but the results are observed to become stable after 10,000 or 100,000 replications.

sec.title: 3.2. Model and Adjustment Strategies
sec.p: For each simulated data set, the discrete-time hazard model is used to estimate the effect of the treatment condition on the probability of event occurrence. There are three adjustment strategies to evaluate the effect of the covariate on increasing the treatment effect detection power. The first strategy adjusts the treatment effect using a predefined covariate; it always includes the covariate in the model and is called the prespecified strategy. In the second strategy, the covariate is considered for adjustment if it has a significant effect on the outcome in a model without the treatment condition as a predictor variable (using the Wald test statistic and p < .05); it is called the significant-predictor strategy. The third strategy defines another constraint for adjustment; it only includes a covariate in the model if it is significantly correlated with the treatment (imbalance allocation) and is called the significant-imbalance strategy. The imbalance allocation is assessed on the basis of the Pearson chi-square test with 1 df (p < .05).

sec.title: 3.3. Criteria for Evaluation
sec.p:
To evaluate the effect of the adjustment strategies on the estimate of the treatment effect (β1) and its standard error, we focus on the relative parameter bias and the relative standard error bias of this parameter. The relative parameter bias is given by:

Muthén and Muthén (2002) suggest that the absolute values of parameter bias and standard error bias should not exceed 10% and 5%, respectively.

The power (probability of rejecting the null hypothesis if it is false) of the treatment effect is estimated using the proportion of the simulated data sets for which the null hypothesis of no treatment effect is rejected in a two-sided test with a default significance level of 5%. This proportion is an estimate of Type I error rate (probability of rejecting the null hypothesis if it is true) for the treatment effect with a population value equal to zero. The Wald statistic is used to evaluate the statistical significance of the treatment and calculated by dividing the treatment effect estimate by its standard error (
W =
β ˆ

E (

1
)
) and referring to the 97.5th quantile of the standard normal distribution.

To identify whether and which adjustment strategies increase the statistical power for β1, we consider the Reduction in sample size (RSS), which is defined as the decrease in the required sample size of an adjustment strategy that gives the same power as an unadjusted model. Following Hernandez et al. (2004), the RSS can be expressed in a percentage by:
R S S
= 100 − 100 ×
Z u
Z a
2

if
Z u
is the average of the standardized Z scores over all the simulated data sets for the unadjusted strategy and
Z a
is the corresponding mean standardized Z score of the adjusted strategy.

sec.title: 4. Results
sec.p:
We first discuss the simulation results for a specific combination of design factors, which yields the lowest power provided there is no attrition. In other words, we first study the case where subjects only leave the study if they experience the event of interest. This combination is defined using a sample size of 200 and a covariate prevalence of 50
%
. In addition, the hazard function for the baseline group decreases over time (
τ
=
1 3
). The percentage of rejection and the RSS for all the treatment and covariate effects are presented in Table 2. The reported values of the rejection column are either the Type I error rate if there is no treatment effect (
O R
(
β
1
) = 1
) or the power of the treatment effect (
O R
(
β
1
) > 1
). Since none of the parameter and standard error biases of the treatment effect exceed their critical values of 10% and 5% in absolute value, they are not given in the table.

Simulation Results With Covariate Prevalence 50%,

. For each combination of
β
1

, the results of the best adjustment strategy are presented in boldface.

sec.p:
Table 2 shows that since a covariate with a large effect is nearly always a predictive covariate, the prespecified and significant-predictor strategies primarily generate similar results for a large covariate effect. Furthermore, if either the unadjusted strategy or the significant-imbalance strategy are used, there are no considerable differences between the results. For a sample size equal to 200, there is hardly ever a significant imbalance allocation during a randomization sequence. For instance, for all the simulation conditions with
N = 200
, an imbalanced allocation solely occurs in less than 7% of the data sets. So the results with the unadjusted and significant-imbalance strategies are almost similar.

As is obvious, given a certain covariate effect, a considerably larger power is observed for a larger treatment effect, but the RSS only slightly changes with different treatment effects. It should also be noted that for a given treatment effect, increasing the covariate effect results in a lower power but a higher RSS. Since these relations are also observed in all the tables below, we do not point them out in the following subsections.

We shall discuss below how the results change if we change the level of the covariate prevalence, sample size, survival pattern, and attrition rate. We only consider the unadjusted and prespecified strategies. Although a slight difference between the prespecified and significant-predictor strategies is observed when the covariate effect is small, in general these two strategies yield similar results. Since the significant-imbalance strategy is also observed to mainly behave in much the same way as the unadjusted strategy, the significant-predictor and significant-imbalance strategies are not denoted in any of the tables below.

sec.title: 4.1. The Effect of Covariate Prevalence
sec.p:
The results in Table 2 are for trials with a covariate prevalence equal to 50%. Table 3 shows a summary of the results for covariate prevalences of 50% and 10%. It should be noted that with
p = .1
, for all the simulation conditions the parameter and standard error biases are never larger than 5% in absolute value. So a smaller covariate prevalence results in smaller parameter biases.

sec.p:
Using different covariate prevalences, inconsiderable differences in the Type I error rates are found and they are all close to their nominal values. If
p = .1
, the power estimate with the prespecified strategy is similar to or slightly higher than on the basis of the unadjusted strategy, particularly if the covariate effect is small, though for a larger covariate effect, the adjusted power has somewhat larger values than the unadjusted one for
p = .5
. As a result, only modest values for the RSS are observed if one uses a much smaller covariate prevalence of 10%.
With a smaller covariate prevalence, the power is higher and the RSS is smaller than in the case of a larger prevalence.

sec.title: 4.2. The Effect of the Sample Size
sec.p: To study the effect of the sample size on the strategies, we examine the results for various sample sizes and present them in Table 4. Using different sample sizes does not affect the Type I error rates and they differ slightly from their nominal level of 5%. The power of any treatment and covariate effect increases if the sample size increases. There is no clear relation between the RSS and the sample size. In other words, the results indicate a similar RSS with different sample sizes.

sec.title: 4.3. The Effect of the Survival Pattern
sec.p:
To address the performance of the strategies under various hazard probability functions, the results based on three different survival patterns (
τ
=

sec.p:
Almost all the Type I error rates are close to the nominal level across all the strategies when different hazard probability functions are used. There is a curvilinear relation between the power (and thus the reduction in sample size) and the survival pattern if the covariate effect is small: The lowest power and reduction are achieved with
τ
=
1 3
and the most adequate power and potential reduction are achieved when τ is set at 1 instead of 3. The results indicate that the distinction between the power levels for
τ
= 1
and
τ
= 3
decreases while the covariate effect increases to a mild effect. For a large covariate effect, the relation appears to be fairly linear and a much higher power and reduction is achieved when τ increases from
1 3
to 3, that is, the largest power and reduction are indicated by
τ
= 3
.

sec.p:
No sizable differences between Type I errors with all the strategies or for any covariate effect are observed when different attrition rates are used. Compared with no attrition, the power is slightly reduced with all the strategies with a mild attrition rate (
r = 0.10
), and moderately reduced with
r = 0.25
. With the same comparison, in general the RSS is slightly reduced when the attrition rate increases. In other words, the higher the attrition rate, the smaller the reduction in sample size.

Finally, the same strategy performance differences and similarities are found for each combination of the levels of
p
,
N
, τ,
r
, β1, and β2. However, the increase in power with the significant-imbalance strategy is slightly higher if τ increases from
1 3
to 3. We observe similar results for the effect of the design factors in all the other simulation conditions. Despite the commonalities of the results, the effect of the survival pattern on the power is curvy in all the covariate effects for a smaller covariate prevalence of 10%. Moreover, in this case, the reduction in sample size for some combinations of the treatment and covariate effects does not decrease when the attrition rate increases.

sec.title: 5. When Is It Worth Measuring a Covariate?
sec.p: We now return to the question of whether it is more cost-efficient to increase the power using a covariate than by increasing the sample size. To answer the question, we consider RCTs with two treatment groups of equal size and without attrition. We assume that the duration of the study consists of P time periods. Following Jóźwiak and Moerbeek (2012), two cost functions are defined for the trial. The first function assumes that all the subjects are tracked until the end of the trial even if they experience the event in a previous period. The second function assumes that the subjects are not followed after the event occurs. In this study, we only focus on the first function and assume that the treatment is implemented only at the beginning of the study so that the treatment costs do not depend on the number of time periods the subject remains in the study.

The cost function for an unadjusted design with the covariate not added to the model can be defined as:
C u
=
N u
C e
+
C c
2
+
C 1
+
N u
P
C m
=
N u
(
C s
+ P
C m
) .

C u
are the total costs and
C 1
the costs of sampling and recruiting one subject.
C e
and
C c
are the implementation costs for each subject in the experimental and control group respectively.
C m
are the costs of taking one measurement at the end of each time period for each subject. P is the number of time periods and
N u
represents the total unadjusted sample size needed to achieve the desired power
1 −
β
. We set the whole expression in brackets in the left side as
C s
and these are the costs of sampling, recruiting, and implementing each intervention for a new subject and are to be called the costs at the subject level.
C s
+ P
C m
are the total costs for each subject in the unadjusted design. The cost function for an adjusted design, which includes a covariate in the model, can be expressed by
C a
=
N a
(
C s
+ P
C m
+
C
c o v
)
.
C
c o v
are the additional costs for each subject for measuring the covariate, as is done once at the beginning of the study.
N a
is the adjusted required number of subjects to achieve the same power.

It is worth measuring a covariate if the following inequality is observed:
C u
>
C a
⇒
N u
(
C s
+ P
C m
) >
N a
(
C s
+ P
C m
+
C
c o v
) .

This means the total costs of a trial without a covariate at the power of
1 −
β
are larger than the total costs of a trial with a covariate at the same level of power. The RSS is defined above as the reduction in sample size of an adjusted design to give the same power as an unadjusted design. In addition, the RSS on the basis of the unadjusted and adjusted sample sizes can be written as:
So measuring the covariate is cost-efficient if

Using a covariate is thus preferable if the additional costs for measuring the covariate are low relative to
C s
+ P
C m
or if the RSS is sufficiently high.

The matrix of plots in Figure 2 shows the cost ratio
C a

as a function of the RSS on the horizontal axes, the number of periods in the columns (P = 2 and 8), and the costs of obtaining a measurement at the end of each period in the rows, which are defined relative to the costs at the subject level:

. Within each plot, the four lines represent four different values of the costs of measuring a covariate, relative to the costs at the subject level in the unadjusted design:

sec.p:
For each combination of P and
C m
, the cost ratio is smaller if
C

or if the RSS is larger. It is also clear that the cost ratio for a smaller
C

C a

at smaller values of the RSS. The cost ratio also decreases if P increases or

C m
C s

C m
and P, the lines of the cost ratios almost overlap and intersect the line
C a
C u
= 1
at small values of the RSS. Therefore, using a covariate can be claimed to be worthwhile even if measuring the covariate is rather expensive.

The main conclusion here is that increasing the power to detect a treatment effect by including a covariate in the model is more cost-efficient if the costs of measuring the covariate are small and the reduction in sample size is large. A low-cost covariate (
C
c o v
= 0.1
C s
) almost always results in
C a
C u
< 1
, so measuring the covariate and using fewer subjects to increase the power are recommended. For higher costs, using a covariate may be preferred for more numerous time periods (P = 10) or higher measurement costs (
C m
= 4
C s
) but would be discouraged for the reverse conditions. For a reduction in sample size larger than 50%, it is always a good idea to use a covariate even if measuring the covariate is twice as expensive as the subject level costs.

sec.title: 6.1. The Effect of Behavior Couples Therapy on Drinking Behavior
sec.p: We consider a study used in Masyn’s dissertation (Masyn, 2003) as an example to illustrate the strategy presented in this article. The main purposes of the study in Masyn (2003) were to assess the efficacy of behavior couples therapy (BCT) on drinking behavior of alcohol dependent males and also to find the relationship between drinking and domestic violence. In this study, there were three counseling treatment programs: marital treatment (BCT), individual-based treatment, and attention control treatment. The sample size in these conditions were 56, 56, and 58, respectively, and measurements were taken each 2 months for a period of 1 year. Masyn estimated the effect of BCT relative to the other two programs and the sole covariate indicated whether the wife’s education was beyond high school (71 cases) or not (99 cases).

The results in table 2.4 in Masyn’s dissertation are chosen as values for the effect of BCT treatment (
β
1
= − 0.59
) and wife’s education (
β
2
= − 0.62
), and also for the six baseline logit hazards
α
j
( − 0.99 ,
− 1.82 ,
− 2.10 ,
− 2.44 ,
− 2.80 ,
− 3.07 )
. We set our simulation factors’ levels to these values and discuss the results. As the original study, we assume that 42% of subjects are with wives with no eduction beyond high school (p = .42), 33% of subjects are allocated to BCT, and all of the subjects complete the survey (
r = 0.00
). So, this example shows our strategy can also be used for trials with allocation ratios, covariate prevalences, and number of time points that are different from the ones that were used in the previous sections and the survival function does not necessarily have to be Weibull.

We may assume that measuring the covariate is much less expensive than the total costs to recruit couples and implement the programs (
C
c o v
≪
C s
+
C m
). Thus, to minimize the costs while maximizing the power, taking the covariate into account is worthwhile from a statistical and also from a financial point of view. One might notice that we suppose the study is planned not only to study event occurrence but also to obtain knowledge about returning to drinking alcohol and its consequences such as violence. Therefore, the subjects will remain in the study even if their event is observed, as is the underlying assumption in the cost functions in the previous section.

sec.title: 6.2. The Effect of a Prevention Program on Math Course-Taking History
sec.p: A study by Graham (1997) followed 3,790 high school students from 10th grade through the third semester of college and showed many of them drop out from mathematics class. In addition, the dropout rate was higher for girls than it was for boys. There might be a plethora of strategies to prevent future students from terminating math class such as offering tutoring sessions, establishing learning communities, or conducting an enhanced academic curriculum designed to improve student’s math by additional lectures and assignments. We assume a study that assesses the effect of a dropout prevention program on the risk of students’ mathematics career by tracking them at five different points in time.

Before conducting such a study, one needs to compute the required sample size for achieving a desired power. To do so, one needs to specify the model parameters’ values (baseline hazard probabilities) from the literature and a realistic guess of the program effect. It might also be of interest to investigate the effect of a covariate like gender on increasing power. We use the findings of the study by Graham (1997) as presented in table 12.5 of Singer and Willett (2003) as the baseline logit hazard probabilities of boys in the control condition
α
j
= ( − 2.13 ,
− 0.94 ,
− 1.45 ,
− 0.62 ,
− 0.77 )
and the gender effect
β
2
= 0.38
for the proportional discrete-time hazard model. Not only is the survival function not a Weibull function but also the logit hazard function zig-zags over time.

The regression coefficient for the intervention program is chosen
β
1
= − 0.36
, which corresponds to a difference of almost 10% between the two treatment conditions in proportion of the students who remain in math course by the end of the study. In other words, by the end of the third semester of college, 22% of the girls who are enrolled in the intervention program will complete their mathematics courses compared to 13% of those who are not. The alternative proportions for the boys are 34% in the intervention condition in comparison to 23
%
in the control condition. Assume we sample 600 students and half of them are randomly assigned to the hypothetical intervention program. Since the gender effect is small, we also investigate the use of covariate adjustment for a mild (
β
2
= 0.69
) and a large (
β 2
= 1.1
) gender effect.

A simulation study indicates that adjustment of the program effect for gender yields a reduction in required sample size of 2.4%, 7.9%, and 17.8%, corresponding to the small, mild, and large
β
2
, respectively. With the largest RSS, the prespecified strategy increases power from 83% of the unadjusted design to 90% of the adjusted design. We conclude that for an RCT of 600 students at a specific level of power, the prespecified strategy requires a sample size 18% smaller to attain the same level of power. Therefore, one needs 493 students to yield 83% power to detect the real effect of the intervention program if the effect is adjusted for an appropriate strong covariate that substantially influences the risk of the dropout. Sample sizes equal to 553 and 586 are needed for a mild and small covariate effect.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions and Discussion
sec.p: The main purpose of this article is to investigate the extent to which using a predictive covariate increases the power of treatment effect detection. Three different covariate adjustment approaches are compared in a simulated discrete-time hazard model. Based on a simulation study, their performances over various design factor combinations are identified. In this study, the power gain achieved using the adjustment strategies is expressed as the potential reduction in sample size that gives the same power as an unadjusted design.

The overall results indicate that for any combination of τ,
β
1
,
β
2
,
N
,
p
, and
r
, the prespecified strategy tends to increase the unadjusted power of the treatment effect, and this increase is somewhat greater for a larger covariate effect. The significant-predictor strategy increases the unadjusted power only slightly in comparison with the prespecified strategy if the covariate effect is small. For a larger covariate effect, these two strategies generate roughly the same results. The significant-imbalance strategy only slightly changes the unadjusted power. As a result, the potential reductions in sample size are found with the prespecified and significant-predictor strategies if the covariate effect is large, and the significant-imbalance strategy shows much smaller or even negligible reductions. The power depends on the treatment and covariate effect. A greater observed power value is found with a smaller covariate and larger treatment effect. The reduction in sample size mostly depends on the covariate effect and only slightly on the treatment effect. In other words, a larger reduction is observed for a stronger covariate effect and varies negligibly if the treatment effect changes. The power and reduction are observed to depend on the covariate prevalence. For much smaller covariate prevalence, a higher power and smaller reduction are observed. In addition, the power is highly influenced by taking different sample sizes and increases with a larger sample size. However, the reduction barely changes with different sample sizes. In conclusion, the reduction does not depend on the treatment effect and sample size. The power and reduction also depend on the shape of the hazard probability function. The Weibull distribution with a small value of τ (
τ
=
1 3
) results in the lowest observed value of power and the smallest reduction. For designs with a constant risk of event occurrence (
τ
= 1
), the higher power and reduction are achieved with a small covariate effect. If the Weibull survival with
τ
= 3
is applied, more sufficient power and more potential reduction are observed for a stronger covariate effect. Moreover, the attrition rate slightly impacts the power and reduction in sample size; the higher the attrition rate, the lower the power and reduction in sample size.

Our findings support evidence of a substantial gain in power when a strong predictive covariate is included in the model, especially in trials with 50% covariate prevalence, without attrition, and with the probability of an event concentrated toward the end of the study (
τ
= 3
). However, the covariate does not increase the power if the correlation between the outcome and the covariate is not strong enough. In this case, even a prespecified strategy does not increase power much and only slightly reduces the sample size. We recommend using the prespecified strategy if a strong predictive covariate is known before the trial is conducted. An alternative can be the significant-predictor strategy if researchers do not know a strong predictive covariate in advance. Since the underlying survival function influences the effect of the covariate adjustment strategies, the shape of the survival function needs to be specified in the planning phase of a trial. Researchers can often guess the survival parameters based on some prior information or findings in the literature. For example, the Weibull shape parameter τ might be expected to be larger than 1 or lie between
1 3
and 1. In practice, particularly in longitudinal studies, subjects may leave a trial for unforeseen reasons other than experiencing an event. Since the attrition impacts the power and consequently the reduction, researchers should expect a certain attrition rate if they want to design the trials efficiently. This is why we encourage researchers to consider these factors when designing their investigations.

Although using the covariate can increase the power without increasing the sample size, one should always consider the costs of measuring the covariate. If the costs of measuring a covariate are not offset by the reduction in sample size needed to achieve a desired level of power, using the covariate is not advisable. The second aim of the study was to quantify when measuring a covariate is more cost-efficient. In general, a covariate with costs 10 times lower than the costs at the subject level
(
C
c o v
= 0.1
C s
)
is highly recommended for increasing the statistical power. For higher costs, a covariate is preferable if the trial is long and the costs of obtaining one measurement are considerably higher than the costs at the subject level
(
C m
= 4
C s
)
. In other words, a longer duration and relatively high measurement costs are conditions that warrant a covariate adjustment for increasing the power. A sufficient reduction in sample size, as is achieved using a strong predictive covariate, always produces a condition that including a covariate should probably be considered for. On the whole, if a covariate can be measured at a negligible cost, it is advisable to measure it, regardless of whether one will use it later in the model for increasing power.

This study focuses primarily on assumptions such as the Weibull distribution with scale parameter
λ
= −
l o g (
1 −
ω
)
equal to 1.61 (
ω
= 0.8
), an equal sample size in both treatment conditions at the beginning of the study, and the maximum length of five time periods for all the subjects. The findings are restricted to simulation results with plausible treatment and covariate effects rather than real data. In addition, we only consider covariate prevalences of 10% and 50%; results with a covariate prevalence of 90% are similar to those with a 10% covariate prevalence. We have not addressed the consequences of covariate adjustment strategies with more than one covariate available. Nor have we studied the effect of strategies using a continuous covariate. Future research might modify these assumptions, for instance unequal allocation to the treatment conditions, various numbers of time periods, and different plausible values for ω such as 0.5 and 0.2. Finding an optimal combination of the design factors using optimality criteria to maximize power while minimizing the costs might also be a topic for future research. The results of the cost section can only be taken as evidence of trials with subjects followed until the end of the study, even if they already experienced the event. So the findings do not have any implications as regards trials that study surviving a disease in subjects only observed until death. In such cases, comparing the two alternative cost functions for increasing power is more complicated since the number of measurements depends on the periods during which the subjects remain in the study in each treatment condition.

To our knowledge, this is the first study on increasing power using a predictive covariate for trials with discrete-time survival endpoints. In conclusion, we hope our findings help researchers in the social and behavioral sciences increase power by including a strong predictive covariate while reducing the financial trial costs.
